I visited Bandar Abbas on the 23rd November and personally inspected the buildings. Large cracks have appeared in some of the walls, and it is obvious even to the layman that unless steps are taken to carry out the repairs without delay there is a serious risk of a portion of the building collapsing.Hi^ Majesty*s Consul has temporarily vacated his office for fear of this occurring. The additions and alterations involve the replacement of cement by Sind patent tiles and ruberoid. I understand that this will effect a considerable reduction of weight on the supporting walls and will also avoid the cracking to which cement is so liable. In these circumstances, I trust the Government of India will be pleased to sanction these additions and I would ask that their administrative approval both to the special repairs and to the additions may be conveyed by telegram. physicalDescription.extent: The papers are arranged in approximate chronological order from the rear to the front of the file.

Foliation: the foliation sequence (used for referencing) commences at the front cover with 1, and terminates at the inside back cover with 19; these numbers are written in pencil, are circled, and are located in the top right corner of the recto side of each folio.

mods.abstract: The file concerns repairs to the Consulate buildings at Bandar Abbas.The file is composed solely of internal correspondence between the Foreign Office, the Government of India and the Political Residency in the Persian Gulf.
